Example

Another interesting result can be discovered by considering the function \[ f(t) = \begin{cases} 0 \hspace{1cm} - \pi < t < 0 \\ t^2 \hspace{1cm} 0 < t < \pi \end{cases} \] \[ f(t + 2\pi ) = f(t) \] shown in the Figure below



This has Fourier series \[ \begin{align} \dfrac{\pi^2}{6} &- 2 \left( \cos t - \dfrac{ \cos 2t}{4} + \dfrac{ \cos 3t}{9} - \dots \right) \\ &+ \left\{ \left( \pi -\dfrac{4}{\pi} \right) \sin t - \dfrac{\pi}{2} \sin 2t + \left( \dfrac{\pi}{3} - \dfrac{4}{9\pi} \right) \sin 3t - \dfrac{\pi}{4} \sin 4t + \dots \right\} \end{align} \] If we now set \(t = \pi\), all of the sine terms become zero, and we are left with \[ \begin{align} \dfrac{\pi^2}{6} - &2 \left( \cos \pi - \dfrac{ \cos 2\pi}{4} + \dfrac{ \cos 3\pi}{9} - \dots \right) \\ &= \dfrac{\pi^2}{6} - 2 \left( -1 - \dfrac{1}{4} - \dfrac{1}{9} - \dfrac{1}{16} - \dots \right) = \dfrac{\pi^2}{6} + 2 \left( 1 + \dfrac{1}{4} + \dfrac{1}{9} + \dfrac{1}{16} + \dots \right) \end{align} \] At \(t = \pi\) the Fourier series will converge to \[ \dfrac{1}{2} (\pi^2 + 0) = \dfrac{\pi^2}{2} \] (the average of the left and right hand limits).

So \[ \dfrac{\pi^2}{6} + 2 \left( 1 + \dfrac{1}{4} + \dfrac{1}{9} + \dfrac{1}{16} + \dots \right) = \dfrac{\pi^2}{2} \] \[ \therefore 1 + \dfrac{1}{4} + \dfrac{1}{9} + \dfrac{1}{16}+ \dots = \dfrac{1}{2} \left( \dfrac{\pi^2}{2} - \dfrac{\pi^2}{6} \right) = \dfrac{\pi^2}{6} \]
Note also that if we substitute \(t = 0\) in the Fourier series (which converges to \(f(0) = 0\)) we obtain another infinite series but with alternating signs: \[ \dfrac{\pi^2}{6} - 2 \left( 1 - \dfrac{1}{4} + \dfrac{1}{9} - \dfrac{1}{16} + \dots \right) = 0\] or \[ 1 - \dfrac{1}{4} + \dfrac{1}{9} - \dfrac{1}{16} + \dots = \dfrac{\pi^2}{12} \]
